[Starship "Firestorm"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is in space.

--
Star Conquest Help: Socials
--
Category: Communication
--
The following social commands are available:
alugh       amuse       bat         beam        beckon      
blink       blush       bounce      bow         cackle      
cheer       chortle     chuckle     clap        collapse    
cough       cower       cry         cuddle      curtsy      
duck        envy        eskimo      eyebrow     flap        
flick       footsie     frown       furrow      gag         
gasp        gawk        gaze        gesture     giggle      
girn        glance      glare       glower      gnaw        
grin        groan       growl       grumble     grunt       
headshake   hiccup      high        hop         hug         
hum         knock       laugh       lean        lick        
moan        mumble      mutter      nibble      nod         
nudge       nuzzle      owl         pace        pat         
pet         point       poke        ponder      pout        
push        quiz        rolleyes    rub         salute      
scoff       scowl       scream      scuff       shake       
shiver      shriek      shrug       shudder     sigh        
smile       smirk       smooch      snap        snarl       
sneer       sneeze      snicker     sniffle     snore       
snort       snuggle     sob         squawk      squeak      
squeeze     squint      stare       stomp       stretch     
tap         thumb       tickle      wave        wheeze      
whimper     whistle     wince       wink        wist        
wrap        wrinkle     yawn        
For more interesting ways to use these commands, please read the Advanced
Socials help file!

l
[Starship "William Dove"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a sleek metal quantum entanglement communication device, a rattan floor
lamp with a light purple lotus shade (casting a white-colored glow), a wormhole
drive tracer, a dark purple leather captain's chair, a large oval white and
black cloth rug, a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white and
sapphire star quilt on it, a small white trash bin, a round white rattan coffee
table with a glass top, a wall-sized bubbling neon purple-lit aquarium
containing yellow and red aquatic life and coral rocks, a blue plastic food
storage container, a compact red refrigerator, a small blue insulated cooler, a
clear plastic food storage container, a glossy purple ceramic felo chow bowl,
Purr the humanoid service robot, a high tech silver star print holovid, Shule
Elemmire's workbench, and a sheet of white paper here.
Lily Kaise is standing here.
You can go south and out.

l anaconda
the eight-person soothsayer mark two "Anaconda"
You see a cruiser here.
"Anaconda" is written along its hull in blocky silver letters.
The designation "AH-12b" is stamped in tiny letters near its landing struts.
This starship advertises its function with its form. It does not look
particularly flightworthy, with protruding turrets, communications equipment,
and a box-like protrusion in the rear where the reactionless drive and wormhole
drive reside. But, of course, it is not intended to fly through an atmosphere. A
small protrusion on the nose of the vessel is its main sensor relay. Only the
bottom appears smooth, and even that is marred by the extension of its landing
struts when not in flight.
The hull is gleaming and painted a deep green color with silver trim. Its laser
turrets are sleek and dangerous-looking and outlined in silver. The bays of its
minicannon launchers are oiled to perfection and painted silver. Its landing
struts are flawless and strong and painted gunmetal grey.
It has a silver AEU logo forward on the starboard side, a geodesic radome, a
smooth dome, and a single large port covered by an iris-style hatch on the
forward end, and the hull has an odd sheen to it, as if covered in a thin
gossamer webbing.
transport anaconda
The eight-person soothsayer mark two "Anaconda" is loaded onto an automated
flatbed and slowly moved into a large garage.
transport
There are no ships here.

You see a sleek metal quantum entanglement communication device, a rattan floor

drive tracer, a dark purple leather captain's chair, a large oval white and

table with a glass top, a wall-sized bubbling neon purple-lit aquarium

clear plastic food storage container, a glossy purple ceramic felo chow bowl,

l comm
a secondary pilot command access unit
This is a book-sized unit of electronics, with a stainless steel plate on one
side and an exposed circuit board on the other. A multi-pronged metal plug
extends from one edge, the right size and shape to interface with a starship
control board.
put comm in case
You put a secondary pilot command access unit in a black engineering tool case.

automated flatbed, then lowered to the floor.

microphone, and a miniature loudspeaker.

[Manhattan Spaceport; Pilot Lounge]
Seemingly wedged in the extra space between two other rooms, this lounge is very
narrow but extends far back, giving it enough room to seat quite a few people.
The light from the suspended lamps is warm and easy on the eyes, casting
everything in a rich golden glow, and the booths are padded and comfortable. The
walls are decorated with countless replicas of old flags and yellowing paper
maps of Earth's various countries. A tiny holovid nestled at the far edge of
each booth shows both a view of the landing pad outside and the latest news
broadcasts. There is a stairway at the back of the room that leads to the
garage.
You see a lacquered wooden bar, a public holovid, a small red trash can, a
brightly-lit candy vending machine, and a salt lick here.
Shraga Whittaker is sitting on a comfortable wooden chair. Morris Corlew is
sitting on a cushy booth seat. Gregory Bentham, Lillian Hudson, Lily Kaise,
Sakura Arakida, Zandria Marschaund, and Melinda Michaels are standing here.
You can go out.

nearest holovid, where the image of a ship can be seen landing on the outside
landing pad. An informative bit of text below it identifies it as the two-person
heavy launch vessel "Registered Merchant 179".

Lily Kaise
She appears to be 27 years old. She is about five feet and two inches tall and
has fair skin. Her body is thin with attractively curved hips and shapely
calves. She has slender shoulders and slightly larger than average breasts. Her
face is oval and pretty, with a delicate nose and understated chin. Her lips are
lovely and blush pink and occasionally part to reveal a set of pretty teeth.
Beneath a set of arched eyebrows, her eyes are blue-green and almond-shaped. Her
waist-length, straight hair is pale honey blonde and swept up into a thick fall
of loose curls down her back. She has oval pink fingernails.
A small enameled cerulean blue dragonfly pierces her left earlobe and a small
enameled cerulean blue dragonfly pierces her right earlobe.
She is wearing a long-sleeved dark blue tee appliqued with small neon pink
dragonflies, a pair of skinny faded blue low rise jeans, and a pair of sparkly
white leather clogs.
She is also wearing an orange and white blessed prayer bracelet around her
wrist, a slender bracelet of tiny tinkling silver bells around her wrist, a neon
purple wrist-mounted chronometer, a solid silver ring engraved with dragonflies,
a delicate ring of silver wire and small purple amethyst crystals, a metallic
gold touch einrophone in a metallic purple reinforced plastic phone holster, and
a soft fuchsia Tardick lizard snuggly labeled 'Asteria'.
Her head, face, both eyes, neck, both wrists, both hands, and waist are left
uncovered.
She is carrying a mug of hot rich Italian coffee in her right hand.

[Starship "The Shame Squad Prevails"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is in space.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, and a black leather
captain's chair here.
Lillian Hudson, Lily Kaise, Morris Corlew, Gregory Bentham, Sakura Arakida,
Zandria Marschaund, and Melinda Michaels are standing here.
You can go south and out.
Lily Kaise laughs.

moment.

weapons room you're in."

[Starship "The Shame Squad Prevails"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is in space.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, and a black leather
captain's chair here.
Sakura Arakida, Lily Kaise, Melinda Michaels, Zandria Marschaund, Lillian
Hudson, Gregory Bentham, and Morris Corlew are standing here.
You can go south and out.
The starship transitions into another sector.

A planet once existed here, until it was destroyed by the Outsiders. Now only
large chunks of the planet remain, still drifting slowly away from each other,
with clouds of debris filling the sector.
A circular space station dominates this sector, made of darkened metal
reinforced against attack. By the look of it, this is probably the most heavily
armored station in human space, excepting The Torus. This is the heart of the
Accord of Free Worlds.
Via general sector communication, Accord of Free Worlds Command transmits,
"Hello, The Shame Squad Prevails. Welcome to Accord space."

[Starship "The Shame Squad Prevails"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is in space.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, and a black leather
captain's chair here.

Earthgate Station dominates space here, acting as a watchpost for the approach
to Old Earth.
Old Earth turns below you, blue and green and brown and white. The planet
elicits a feeling of "home" in almost all who view it, even if they have never
actually set foot on it.

[Starship "William Dove"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is at New Earth; Spaceport Landing Pad.

l dove
the five-person A.S.S. tactical platform "William Dove"
You see a gunship here.
"William Dove" is written along its hull in blocky silver letters.
The designation "ASS-E7" is stamped in tiny letters near its landing struts.
This starship advertises its function with its form. It does not look
particularly flightworthy, with protruding turrets, communications equipment,
and a box-like protrusion in the rear where the reactionless drive and wormhole
drive reside. But, of course, it is not intended to fly through an atmosphere. A
small protrusion on the nose of the vessel is its main sensor relay. Only the
bottom appears smooth, and even that is marred by the extension of its landing
struts when not in flight.
The hull is faded and slightly scorched and painted a white color with gunmetal
grey trim. Its laser turrets are somewhat scorched and outlined in gunmetal
grey. Its landing struts are rusted and slightly uneven and painted gunmetal
grey.
It has a small shiny black circular section, a series of delicate antennae
encased in a transparisteel dome, and a smooth dome on the forward end.
It has a luxury sightseer, a luxury sightseer, and a luxury sightseer attached
to its base block.

automated flatbed and slowly moved into a large garage.
